Adult Social Care in Oxfordshire

Adult Social Care helps people who are older or living with a disability or other long term health conditions to live independently and stay well and safe. It includes a wide variety of support, including:

 information and advice about activities in the community

providing aids and adaptations

‘reablement’ services to help people after a stay in hospital

support for carers that enables them to maintain their caring role in the way that they choose.

support in people’s own homes such as home care

support in day centres

care provided by care homes and nursing homes.

In Oxfordshire, we have transformed how we work, and structured ourselves to respond to the operating environment based on the belief that we should build our support around what people and communities already have, rather than don’t have. We developed our strategic vision, the Oxfordshire Way, which means supporting people to live well and independently within their communities, remaining fit and healthy for as long as possible. We do this by working with people we support, our communities, our partners and providers, in line with our corporate vision for being the employer, partner and place shaper of choice.

We will keep working with you to offer diverse, affordable, quality, and innovative services to improve how adult social care works for people supported in Oxfordshire.

Karen Fuller 

Director of Adults and Housing Services 

Oxfordshire County Council

In Oxfordshire, social care users have access to a variety of resources and support services, including advocacy and complaints services. **Healthwatch Oxfordshire** plays a key role in gathering information about people's experiences with health and social care services, providing advice, and holding service providers accountable for improvements. They encourage the public to share their experiences to influence service delivery (Document 1).

**Carers Oxfordshire**, a partnership between Action for Carers Oxfordshire and Rethink Mental Illness, offers extensive support for unpaid carers over 18, including information, advice, and support both online and in-person. They also conduct carers’ assessments and provide peer support, training, and short breaks (Documents 5 and 6).

For complaints and advocacy, Oxfordshire County Council provides information on how to make comments, compliments, and complaints about adult social care services. This is part of their commitment to ensuring fair and equitable service delivery and giving users more power and control (Document 3).

Additional resources include the **Live Well Oxfordshire** directory, which offers information on over 2,000 services and community groups, helping individuals find support within their community (Document 10).

For more information or to access these services, visit the following resources:
- Healthwatch Oxfordshire: [Healthwatch Oxfordshire](https://www.oxfordshire.gov.uk/council/about-your-council/have-your-say-about-council-services/influencing-health-care-and-wellbeing-services/healthwatch-oxfordshire)
- Carers Oxfordshire: [Carers Oxfordshire](https://www.oxfordshire.gov.uk/residents/social-and-health-care/carers/all-age-unpaid-carers-strategy)
- Live Well Oxfordshire: [Live Well Oxfordshire](https://www.oxfordshire.gov.uk/business/information-providers/adult-social-care-providers/general-information)

For specific complaints or advocacy services, you can refer to the adult social care policies on the Oxfordshire County Council website.
